09474                     // (So we know if there is still stuff open on Cron for that Nym, and we know what it is.)
09475                     //
09476                     std::set<int64_t> & theIDSet = theNym.GetSetOpenCronItems();
09477                     theIDSet.insert(pTrade->GetTransactionNum());
09478                     theIDSet.insert(pTrade->GetAssetAcctClosingNum());
09479                     theIDSet.insert(pTrade->GetCurrencyAcctClosingNum());
09480                     // ------------------------------------------------------------------
09481                     // This just removes the Closing number so he can't USE it again. (Since he's using it as the closing
09482                     // number for this cron item now.) He's still RESPONSIBLE for the number until RemoveIssuedNumber()
09483                     // is called. If we didn't call this here, then he could come back later and USE THE NUMBER AGAIN!
09484                     // (Bad!) You might ask, why not remove the Opening number as well as the Closing numbers? The answer
09485                     // is, we already did, before we got here. (Otherwise we wouldn't have even gotten this far.)
09486                     //
09487                     RemoveTransactionNumber(theNym, pTrade->GetAssetAcctClosingNum(), false);
09488                     RemoveTransactionNumber(theNym, pTrade->GetCurrencyAcctClosingNum(), false); // (Saved below.)
09489                     // RemoveIssuedNum will be called for the original transaction number when the finalReceipt is created.
09490                     // RemoveIssuedNum will be called for the Closing number when the finalReceipt is accepted.
09491 
09492                     theNym.SaveSignedNymfile(m_nymServer);  // <===== SAVED HERE.
09493                 }
09494                 else
09495                 {
09496                     OTLog::Output(0, "Unable to add trade to Cron object OTServer::NotarizeMarketOffer\n");
09497                 }
09498             }
09499 
09500             // If the trade WAS successfully added to Cron, then we don't need to
09501             // delete it here, since Cron owns it now, and will deal with cleaning
09502             // it up at the right time.
09503             if ((NULL != pTrade) && pResponseItem->GetStatus() != OTItem::acknowledgement)
09504             {
09505                 delete pTrade;
09506                 pTrade = NULL;
09507             }
09508         } // transaction statement verified.
09509 
09510         // --------------------------------------------------------------------
09511     } // if pItem = tranIn.GetItem(OTItem::marketOffer)
09512 
09513     // sign the response item before sending it back (it's already been added to the transaction above)
09514     // Now, whether it was rejection or acknowledgement, it is set properly and it is signed, and it
09515     // is owned by the transaction, who will take it from here.
09516     pResponseItem->SignContract(m_nymServer);
09517     pResponseItem->SaveContract(); // the signing was of no effect because I forgot to save. (fixed.)
09518 
09519     pResponseBalanceItem->SignContract(m_nymServer);
09520     pResponseBalanceItem->SaveContract();
09521 }
09522 
09523 
09524 
09525 
09526 
09531 void OTServer::NotarizeTransaction(OTPseudonym & theNym, OTTransaction & tranIn, OTTransaction & tranOut, bool & bOutSuccess)
09532 {
09533     bool bSuccess = bOutSuccess = false;
09534 
09535     const   int64_t         lTransactionNumber = tranIn.GetTransactionNum();
09536     const   OTIdentifier    SERVER_ID(m_strServerID);
09537             OTIdentifier    USER_ID;
09538     theNym.GetIdentifier(   USER_ID);
09539     const OTString strIDNym (USER_ID);
09540 
09541     OTAccount theFromAccount(USER_ID, tranIn.GetPurportedAccountID(), SERVER_ID);
09542 
09543     // Make sure the "from" account even exists...
09544     if (!theFromAccount.LoadContract())
09545     {
09546         const OTString strIDAcct(tranIn.GetPurportedAccountID());
09547         OTLog::vOutput(0, "%s: Error loading asset account: %s\n",
09548                        __FUNCTION__, strIDAcct.Get());
09549     }
09550     // Make sure the "from" account isn't marked for deletion.
09551     else if (theFromAccount.IsMarkedForDeletion())
09552     {
09553         const OTString strIDAcct(tranIn.GetPurportedAccountID());
09554         OTLog::vOutput(0, "%s: Failed attempt to use an Asset account that was marked for deletion: %s\n",
09555                        __FUNCTION__, strIDAcct.Get());
09556     }
09557     // Make sure the Account ID loaded from the file matches the one we just set and used as the filename.
09558     else if (!theFromAccount.VerifyContractID())
09559     {
09560         // this should never happen. How did the wrong ID get into the account file, if the right
09561         // ID is on the filename itself? and vice versa.
09562         const OTString strIDAcct(tranIn.GetPurportedAccountID());
09563         OTLog::vError("%s: Error verifying account ID: %s\n", __FUNCTION__, strIDAcct.Get());
09564     }
09565     // Make sure the nymID loaded up in the account as its actual owner matches the nym who was
09566     // passed in to this function requesting a transaction on this account... otherwise any asshole
09567     // could do transactions on your account, no?
09568     else if (!theFromAccount.VerifyOwner(theNym))
09569     {
09570         const OTIdentifier idAcct(theFromAccount);
09571         const OTString     strIDAcct(idAcct);
09572         OTLog::vOutput(0, "%s: Error verifying account ownership... Nym: %s  Acct: %s\n",
09573                        __FUNCTION__, strIDNym.Get(), strIDAcct.Get());
09574     }
09575     // Make sure I, the server, have signed this file.
09576     else if (!theFromAccount.VerifySignature(m_nymServer))
09577     {
09578         const OTIdentifier idAcct(theFromAccount);
09579         const OTString     strIDAcct(idAcct);
09580         OTLog::vError("%s: Error verifying server signature on account: %s for Nym: %s\n",
09581                       __FUNCTION__, strIDAcct.Get(), strIDNym.Get());
09582     }
09583     // No need to call VerifyAccount() here since the above calls go above and beyond that method.
09584 
09585     else if (!VerifyTransactionNumber(theNym, lTransactionNumber))
09586     {
09587         const OTIdentifier idAcct(theFromAccount);
09588         const OTString     strIDAcct(idAcct);
09589         // The user may not submit a transaction using a number he's already used before.
09590         OTLog::vOutput(0, "%s: Error verifying transaction number %ld on user Nym: %s Account: %s\n",
09591                        __FUNCTION__, lTransactionNumber, strIDNym.Get(), strIDAcct.Get());
09592     }
09593 
09594     // The items' acct and server ID were already checked in VerifyContractID() when they were loaded.
09595     // Now this checks a little deeper, to verify ownership, signatures, and transaction number
09596     // on each item.  That way those things don't have to be checked for security over and over
09597     // again in the subsequent calls.
09598     //
09599     else if (!tranIn.VerifyItems(theNym))
09600     {
09601         const OTIdentifier idAcct(theFromAccount);
09602         const OTString     strIDAcct(idAcct);
09603         OTLog::vOutput(0, "%s: Error verifying transaction items. Trans: %ld Nym: %s  Account: %s\n",
09604                        __FUNCTION__, lTransactionNumber, strIDNym.Get(), strIDAcct.Get());
09605     }
09606 
09607     // any other security stuff?
09608     // Todo do I need to verify the server ID here as well?
09609     else
09610     {
09611         // We don't want any transaction number being used twice.
09612         // (The number, at this point, is STILL issued to the user, who is still responsible
09613         // for that number and must continue signing for it. All this means here is that the
09614         // user no longer has the number on his AVAILABLE list. Removal from issued list happens separately.)
09615         //
09616         if (false == RemoveTransactionNumber(theNym, lTransactionNumber, true)) //bSave=true
09617         {
09618             OTLog::Error("Error removing transaction number (as available) from user nym in OTServer::NotarizeTransaction\n");
09619         }
09620         // -------------------------------------------------------------------
09621         else
09622         {
09623             OTItem::itemType theReplyItemType = OTItem::error_state;
09624 
09625             switch (tranIn.GetType())
09626             {
09627                     // TRANSFER (account to account)
09628                     // Alice sends a signed request to the server asking it to
09629                     // transfer from her account ABC to the inbox of account DEF.
09630                     // A copy will also remain in her outbox until canceled or accepted.
09631                 case OTTransaction::transfer:
09632                     OTLog::Output(0, "NotarizeTransaction type: Transfer\n");
09633                     NotarizeTransfer(theNym, theFromAccount, tranIn, tranOut, bOutSuccess);
09634                     bSuccess = true;
09635                     theReplyItemType = OTItem::atTransfer;
09636                     break;
09637 
09638                     // PROCESS INBOX (currently, all incoming transfers must be accepted.)
09639                     // Bob sends a signed request to the server asking it to reject
09640                     // some of his inbox items and/or accept some into his account DEF.
09641                 case OTTransaction::processInbox:
09642                     OTLog::Output(0, "NotarizeTransaction type: Process Inbox\n");
09643                     NotarizeProcessInbox(theNym, theFromAccount, tranIn, tranOut, bOutSuccess);
09644                     bSuccess = true;
09645 //                  theReplyItemType = OTItem::atProcessInbox; // Nonexistent, and here, unused.
09646                     // (There is a processInbox message that carries that transaction...)
09647                     break;
09648 
09649                     // WITHDRAWAL (cash or voucher)
09650                     // Alice sends a signed request to the server asking it to debit her
09651                     // account ABC and then issue her a purse full of blinded cash tokens
09652                     // --OR-- a voucher (a cashier's cheque, made out to any recipient's
09653                     // User ID, or made out to a blank recipient, just like a blank cheque.)
09654                 case OTTransaction::withdrawal:
09655                 {
09656                     OTItem * pItemVoucher = tranIn.GetItem(OTItem::withdrawVoucher);
09657                     OTItem * pItemCash    = tranIn.GetItem(OTItem::withdrawal);
09658 
09659                     if (NULL != pItemCash)
09660                     {
09661                         theReplyItemType = OTItem::atWithdrawal;
09662                         OTLog::Output(0, "NotarizeTransaction type: Withdrawal (cash)\n");
09663                     }
09664                     else if (NULL != pItemVoucher)
09665                     {
09666                         theReplyItemType = OTItem::atWithdrawVoucher;
09667                         OTLog::Output(0, "NotarizeTransaction type: Withdrawal (voucher)\n");
09668                     }
09669                     // ------------------------------------------------
09670                     NotarizeWithdrawal(theNym, theFromAccount, tranIn, tranOut, bOutSuccess);
09671                     bSuccess = true;
09672                 }
09673                     break;
09674 
09675                     // DEPOSIT  (cash or cheque)
09676                     // Bob sends a signed request to the server asking it to deposit into his
09677                     // account ABC. He includes with his request a signed cheque made out to
09678                     // Bob's user ID (or blank), --OR-- a purse full of tokens.
09679                 case OTTransaction::deposit:
09680                     OTLog::Output(0, "NotarizeTransaction type: Deposit\n");
09681                     NotarizeDeposit(theNym, theFromAccount, tranIn, tranOut, bOutSuccess);
09682                     bSuccess = true;
09683                     theReplyItemType = OTItem::atDeposit;
09684                     break;
09685 
09686                     // PAY DIVIDEND
09687                     // Bob sends a signed request to the server asking it to pay all shareholders
09688                     // of a given asset type at the rate of $X per share, where X and $ are both
09689                     // configurable.
09690                 case OTTransaction::payDividend:
09691                     OTLog::Output(0, "NotarizeTransaction type: Pay Dividend\n");
09692                     NotarizePayDividend(theNym, theFromAccount, tranIn, tranOut, bOutSuccess);
09693                     bSuccess = true;
09694                     theReplyItemType = OTItem::atPayDividend;
09695                     break;
09696 
09697                     // MARKET OFFER
09698                     // Bob sends a signed request to the server asking it to put an offer
09699                     // on the market. He includes with his request a signed trade listing
09700                     // the relevant information, asset types and account IDs.
09701                 case OTTransaction::marketOffer:
09702                     OTLog::Output(0, "NotarizeTransaction type: Market Offer\n");
09703                     NotarizeMarketOffer(theNym, theFromAccount, tranIn, tranOut, bOutSuccess);
09704                     bSuccess = true;
09705                     theReplyItemType = OTItem::atMarketOffer;
09706                     break;
09707 
09708                     // PAYMENT PLAN
09709                     // Bob sends a signed request to the server asking it to make regular
09710                     // payments to Alice. (BOTH Alice AND Bob must have signed the same contract.)
09711                 case OTTransaction::paymentPlan:
09712                     OTLog::Output(0, "NotarizeTransaction type: Payment Plan\n");
09713                     NotarizePaymentPlan(theNym, theFromAccount, tranIn, tranOut, bOutSuccess);
09714                     bSuccess = true;
09715                     theReplyItemType = OTItem::atPaymentPlan;
09716                     break;
09717 
09718                     // SMART CONTRACT
09719                     // Bob sends a signed request to the server asking it to activate a smart contract.
09720                     // Bob is the authorizing agent for one of the parties, all of whom have signed it,
09721                     // and have provided transaction #s for it.
09722                 case OTTransaction::smartContract:
09723                 {
09724                     OTLog::Output(0, "NotarizeTransaction type: Smart Contract\n");
09725 
09726                     // For all transaction numbers used on cron items, we keep track of them in
09727                     // the GetSetOpenCronItems. This will be removed again below, if the transaction
09728                     // fails.
09729                     std::set<int64_t> & theIDSet = theNym.GetSetOpenCronItems();
09730                     theIDSet.insert(lTransactionNumber);
09731                     // ----------------------------------------------
09732                     NotarizeSmartContract(theNym, theFromAccount, tranIn, tranOut, bOutSuccess);
09733                     bSuccess = true;
09734                     theReplyItemType = OTItem::atSmartContract;
09735                 }
09736                     break;
09737 
09738                     // CANCEL CRON ITEM
09739                     // (Cron items: market offers, payment plans...)
09740                     // Bob sends a signed request to the server asking it to cancel a
09741                     // REGULARLY PROCESSING CONTRACT that he had previously created.
09742                 case OTTransaction::cancelCronItem:
09743                     OTLog::Output(0, "NotarizeTransaction type: cancelCronItem\n");
09744                     NotarizeCancelCronItem(theNym, theFromAccount, tranIn, tranOut, bOutSuccess);
09745                     bSuccess = true;
09746                     theReplyItemType = OTItem::atCancelCronItem;
09747                     break;
09748 
09749                     // EXCHANGE BASKET
09750                     // Bob sends a signed request to the server asking it to exchange funds
09751                     // in or out of a basket currency. (From-or-to his main basket account and his
09752                     // various sub-accounts for each member currency in the basket.)
09753                 case OTTransaction::exchangeBasket:
09754                     OTLog::Output(0, "NotarizeTransaction type: Exchange Basket\n");
09755                     NotarizeExchangeBasket(theNym, theFromAccount, tranIn, tranOut, bOutSuccess);
09756                     bSuccess = true;
09757                     theReplyItemType = OTItem::atExchangeBasket;
09758                     break;
09759 
09760                 default:
09761                     OTLog::vError("%s: Error, unexpected type: %s\n", __FUNCTION__, tranIn.GetTypeString());
09762                     break;
09763             }
09764 
09765             // ------------------------------------------
09766 
09767             // Where appropriate, remove a transaction number from my issued list
09768             // (the list of numbers I must sign for in every balance agreement.)
09769             bool bIsCronItem = false;
09770 
09771             switch (tranIn.GetType())
09772             {
09773                 case OTTransaction::marketOffer:
09774                 case OTTransaction::paymentPlan:
09775                 case OTTransaction::smartContract:
09776                     bIsCronItem = true; // Falls through...
09777 
09778                 case OTTransaction::transfer:
09779                     // If success, then Issued number stays on Nym's issued list until the transfer, paymentPlan, marketOffer, or smart
09780                     // contract is entirely closed and removed. In the case of transfer, that's when the transfer receipt is accepted.
09781                     // In the case of markets and paymentplans, that's when they've been entirely removed from Cron (many
09782                     // intermediary receipts might occur before that happens.) At that time, a final receipt is issued with
09783                     // a closing transaction number (to make sure the user closes all of the related market receipts.)
09784                     //
09785                     // But if failure, then Issued number is immediately removed.
09786                     // (It already can't be used again, and there's no receipt to clear later, thus no reason to save it...)
09787                 {
09788                     OTItem * pItem  = tranOut.GetItem(theReplyItemType);
09789 
09790                     if ((NULL != pItem))
09791                     {
09792                         if (OTItem::rejection == pItem->GetStatus())
09793                         {
09794                             // If this is a cron item, then we need to remove it from the
09795                             // list of open cron items as well.
09796                             if (bIsCronItem)
09797                             {
09798                                 std::set<int64_t> & theIDSet = theNym.GetSetOpenCronItems();
09799                                 std::set<int64_t>::iterator theSetIT = theIDSet.find(lTransactionNumber);
09800                                 if (theSetIT != theIDSet.end()) // Found it.
09801                                     theIDSet.erase(lTransactionNumber);
09802                             }
09803                             // --------------------------------------------------------------------
09804                             if (false == RemoveIssuedNumber(theNym, lTransactionNumber, true)) //bSave=true
09805                             {
09806                                 const OTString strNymID(USER_ID);
09807                                 OTLog::vError("%s: Error removing issued number %ld from user nym: %s\n",
09808                                               __FUNCTION__, lTransactionNumber, strNymID.Get());
09809                             }
09810                         }
09811                     }
09812                 }
09813                     break;
09814                 // ------------------------------------------
09815                     // In the case of the below transaction types, the transaction number is removed from the Nym's
09816                     // issued list SUCCESS OR FAIL. (It's closed either way.)
09817                     //
09818                 case OTTransaction::processInbox:
09819                 case OTTransaction::payDividend:
09820                 case OTTransaction::withdrawal:
09821                 case OTTransaction::deposit:
09822                 case OTTransaction::cancelCronItem:
09823                 case OTTransaction::exchangeBasket:
09824                     if (false == RemoveIssuedNumber(theNym, lTransactionNumber, true)) //bSave=true
09825                     {
09826                         const OTString strNymID(USER_ID);
09827                         OTLog::vError("%s: Error removing issued number %ld from user nym: %s\n",
09828                                       __FUNCTION__, lTransactionNumber, strNymID.Get());
09829                     }
09830                     break;
09831                 // ------------------------------------------
09832                 default:
09833                     OTLog::vError("%s: Error, unexpected type: %s\n",
09834                                   __FUNCTION__, tranIn.GetTypeString());
09835                     break;
09836             }
09837         }
09838     }
09839 
09840     // sign the outoing transaction
09841     tranOut.SignContract(m_nymServer);
09842     tranOut.SaveContract();  // don't forget to save (to internal raw file member)
09843 
09844     // Contracts store an internal member that contains the "Raw File" contents
09845     // That is, the unsigned XML portion, plus the signatures, attached in a standard
09846     // PGP-compatible format. It's not enough to sign it, you must also save it into
09847     // that Raw file member variable (using SaveContract) and then you must sometimes
09848     // THEN save it into a file (or a string or wherever you want to put it.)
09849 }
09850 
09851 
09852 
09853 
09854 
09859 void OTServer::UserCmdNotarizeTransactions(OTPseudonym & theNym, OTMessage & MsgIn, OTMessage & msgOut)
09860 {
09861     // (1) set up member variables
09862     msgOut.m_strCommand     = "@notarizeTransactions";  // reply to notarizeTransactions
09863     msgOut.m_strNymID       = MsgIn.m_strNymID;         // UserID
09864     //  msgOut.m_strServerID    = m_strServerID;            // This is already set in ProcessUserCommand.
09865     msgOut.m_strAcctID      = MsgIn.m_strAcctID;        // The Account ID in question
09866 
09867     const OTIdentifier  USER_ID(MsgIn.m_strNymID),
09868         ACCOUNT_ID(MsgIn.m_strAcctID),
09869         SERVER_ID(m_strServerID),
09870         SERVER_USER_ID(m_nymServer);
09871 
09872     OTLedger theLedger(USER_ID, ACCOUNT_ID, SERVER_ID);         // These are ledgers used as messages. The one we received and the one
09873     // that we're sending back in response.
09874     OTLedger * pResponseLedger = OTLedger::GenerateLedger(SERVER_USER_ID, ACCOUNT_ID, SERVER_ID, OTLedger::message, false);
09875     OTCleanup<OTLedger> theRespLedgerGuardian(pResponseLedger); // So I don't have to worry about cleaning it up.
09876     // ----------------
09877 
09878     bool bTransSuccess = false; // for the Nymbox notice.
09879     bool bCancelled    = false; // for "failed" transactions that were actually successful cancellations.
09880 
09881     int64_t lTransactionNumber = 0, lResponseNumber = 0;
09882     // --------------------------
09883     // Since the one going back (above) is a new ledger, we have to call GenerateLedger.
09884     // Whereas the ledger we received from the server was generated there, so we don't
09885     // have to generate it again. We just load it.
09886 
09887     OTString strLedger(MsgIn.m_ascPayload);
09888 
09889     const OTIdentifier  theMsgNymboxHash(MsgIn.m_strNymboxHash);    // theMsgNymboxHash is the hash sent by the client side
09890     OTIdentifier  theSrvrNymboxHash;
09891 
09892     bool bGotNymboxHashServerSide = theNym.GetNymboxHashServerSide(SERVER_ID, theSrvrNymboxHash);
09893 
09894     if (bGotNymboxHashServerSide)  // theSrvrNymboxHash is the hash stored on the server side
09895         theSrvrNymboxHash.GetString(msgOut.m_strNymboxHash);
09896     else {
09897         OTLog::vOutput(1,"%s: We cannot obtain server side nymbox hash, will continue.\n",__FUNCTION__);
09898     }
09899 
09900     const bool bGotNymboxHashClientSide = MsgIn.m_strNymboxHash.Exists();
09901 
09902     if (!bGotNymboxHashClientSide) {
09903         OTLog::vOutput(1, "%s: We don't have a client side nymbox hash, will continue\n", __FUNCTION__);
09904     }
09905 
09906     if (bGotNymboxHashServerSide && bGotNymboxHashClientSide)
09907         if (theMsgNymboxHash != theSrvrNymboxHash) {
09908             OTLog::vOutput(0, "%s: The server and client nymbox hashes missmatch! rejecting message.\n", __FUNCTION__);
09909             goto send_message;
09910         }
09911 
09912 
09913     // as long as the request ledger loads from the message into memory, success is true
09914     // from there, the success or failure of the transactions within will be carried in
09915     // their own status variables and those of the items inside those transactions.
09916     msgOut.m_bSuccess = theLedger.LoadLedgerFromString(strLedger);
09917 
09918     if (msgOut.m_bSuccess)
09919     {
09920         // In this case we need to process the ledger items
09921         // and create a corresponding ledger where each of the new items
09922         // contains the answer to the ledger item sent.
09923         // Then we send that new "response ledger" back to the user in MsgOut.Payload.
09924         // That is all done here. Until I write that, in the meantime,
09925         // let's just fprintf it out and see what it looks like.
09926         //      OTLog::Error("Loaded ledger out of message payload:\n%s\n", strLedger.Get());
09927         //      OTLog::Error("Loaded ledger out of message payload.\n");
09928 
09929         // Loop through ledger transactions, and do a "NotarizeTransaction" call for each one.
09930         // Inside that function it will do the various necessary authentication and processing, not this one.
09931         // NOTE: In practice there is only ONE transaction, but in potential there are many.
09932         // But so far, the code only actually has one, ever being sent. Otherwise the messages
09933         // get too big IMO.
09934         //
09935         int32_t nCounter = 0;
09936         FOR_EACH(mapOfTransactions, theLedger.GetTransactionMap())
09937         {
09938             OTTransaction * pTransaction = (*it).second;
09939             OT_ASSERT(NULL != pTransaction);
09940             ++nCounter;
09941 
09942             if (1 != nCounter)
09943                 OTLog::vError("WARNING: multiple transactions in a single message ledger.\n");
09944 
09945             // for each transaction in the ledger, we create a transaction response and add
09946             // that to the response ledger.
09947 
09948             // I don't call IssueNextTransactionNumber here because I'm not creating a new transaction
09949             // in someone's inbox or outbox. Instead, I'm making a transaction response to a transaction
09950             // request, with a MATCHING transaction number (so don't need to issue a new one) to be sent
09951             // back to the client in a message.
09952             //
09953             // On this new "response transaction", I set the ACCT ID, the serverID, and Transaction Number.
09954             OTTransaction * pTranResponse =
09955                 OTTransaction::GenerateTransaction(*pResponseLedger,
09956                 OTTransaction::error_state, pTransaction->GetTransactionNum());
09957             // Add the response transaction to the response ledger.
09958             // That will go into the response message and be sent back to the client.
09959             pResponseLedger->AddTransaction(*pTranResponse);
09960 
09961             // Now let's make sure the response transaction has a copy of the transaction
09962             // it is responding to.
09963             //              OTString strResponseTo;
09964             //              pTransaction->SaveContract(strResponseTo);
09965             //              pTranResponse->m_ascInReferenceTo.SetString(strResponseTo);
09966             // I commented out the above because we are keeping too many copies.
09967             // Message contains a copy of the message it's responding to.
09968             // Then each transaction contains a copy of the transaction responding to...
09969             // Then each ITEM in each transaction contains a copy of each item it's responding to.
09970             //
09971             // Therefore, for the "notarizeTransactions" message, I have decided (for now) to have
09972             // the extra copy in the items themselves, and in the overall message, but not in the
09973             // transactions. Thus, the above is commented out.
09974 
09975 
09976             // It should always return something. Success, or failure, that goes into pTranResponse.
09977             // I don't think there's need for more return value than that. The user has gotten deep
09978             // enough that they deserve SOME sort of response.
09979             //
09980             // This function also SIGNS the transaction, so there is no need to sign it after this.
09981             // There's also no point to change it after this, unless you plan to sign it twice.
09982             //
09983             NotarizeTransaction(theNym, *pTransaction, *pTranResponse, bTransSuccess);
09984 
09985             if (pTranResponse->IsCancelled())
09986                 bCancelled = true;
09987 
09988             lTransactionNumber = pTransaction->GetTransactionNum();
09989             lResponseNumber    = pTranResponse->GetTransactionNum();
09990 
09991             OT_ASSERT_MSG(lTransactionNumber == lResponseNumber, "Transaction number and response number should always be the same. (But this time, they weren't.)");
09992 
09993             pTranResponse = NULL; // at this point, the ledger now "owns" the response, and will handle deleting it.
09994         }
09995 
09996         // TODO: should consider saving a copy of the response ledger here on the server.
09997         // Until the user signs off of the responses, maybe the user didn't receive them.
09998         // The server should be able to re-send them until confirmation, then delete them.
09999         // So might want to consider a SAVE TO FILE here of that ledger we're sending out...
10000 
10001         // sign the ledger
10002         pResponseLedger->SignContract(m_nymServer);
10003         pResponseLedger->SaveContract();
10004 
10005         // extract the ledger in ascii-armored form
10006         OTString strPayload(*pResponseLedger);
10007 
10008         msgOut.m_ascPayload.SetString(strPayload);  // now the outgoing message has the response ledger in its payload.
10009     }
10010     else
10011     {
10012         OTLog::Error("ERROR loading ledger from message in OTServer::UserCmdNotarizeTransactions\n");
10013     }
10014 
10015 send_message:
10016     // ---------------------------------------------------------------
10017     // todo: consider commenting this out since the transaction reply items already include a copy
10018     // of the original client communication that the server is responding to. No point beating a
10019     // dead horse.
10020     //
10021     // Send the user's command back to him as well.
10022     {
10023         OTString tempInMessage(MsgIn);
10024         msgOut.m_ascInReferenceTo.SetString(tempInMessage);
10025     }
10026 
10027     // -------------------------------------------------------
10028     // UPDATE NYMBOX HASH IN OUTGOING MESSAGE
10029     //
10030     // We already grabbed the server's NymboxHash near the top of this function,
10031     // and attached it to the outgoing reply message.
10032     //
10033     // However, the above block may have CHANGED this hash! Therefore, we grab it
10034     // AGAIN, just in case. This way a failed message will receive the old hash,
10035     // and a successful message will receive the new hash.
10036     //
10037     bGotNymboxHashServerSide = theNym.GetNymboxHashServerSide(SERVER_ID, theSrvrNymboxHash);
10038     if (bGotNymboxHashServerSide)  // theSrvrNymboxHash is the hash stored on the server side
10039         theSrvrNymboxHash.GetString(msgOut.m_strNymboxHash);
10040     // -------------------------------------------------------
10041 
10042     // (2) Sign the Message
10043     msgOut.SignContract(m_nymServer);
10044 
10045     // (3) Save the Message (with signatures and all, back to its internal member m_strRawFile.)
10046     //
10047     // FYI, SaveContract takes m_xmlUnsigned and wraps it with the signatures and ------- BEGIN  bookends
10048     // If you don't pass a string in, then SaveContract saves the new version to its member, m_strRawFile
10049     msgOut.SaveContract();
10050 
10051     // (You are in UserCmdNotarizeTransactions.)
10052 
10053     // *************************************************************
10054     // REPLY NOTICE TO NYMBOX
10055     //
10056     // Now that we signed / saved the reply message...
10057     //
10058     // After EVERY / ANY transaction, we drop a notice with a copy of the server's reply
10059     // into the Nymbox.  This way we are GUARANTEED that the Nym will receive and process
10060     // it. (And thus never get out of sync.)
10061     //
10062     if (msgOut.m_bSuccess)
10063     {
10064         const OTString strReplyMessage(msgOut);
10065         const int64_t lReqNum = atol(MsgIn.m_strRequestNum.Get());
10066 
10067         // If it fails, it logs already.
10068         //      this->DropReplyNoticeToNymbox(SERVER_ID, USER_ID, strReplyMessage, lReqNum, bTransSuccess, &theNym); // We don't want to update the Nym in this case (I don't think.)
10069         this->DropReplyNoticeToNymbox(SERVER_ID, USER_ID, strReplyMessage, lReqNum,
10070             bTransSuccess);    // trans success
10071     }
10072     // -----------
10073     if (bCancelled)
10074     {
10075         OTLog::vOutput(0, "Success: canceling transaction %ld for nym: %s \n",
10076             lTransactionNumber, msgOut.m_strNymID.Get());
10077     }
10078     else if (bTransSuccess)
10079     {
10080         OTLog::vOutput(0, "Success: processing transaction %ld for nym: %s \n",
10081             lTransactionNumber, msgOut.m_strNymID.Get());
10082     }
10083     else
10084     {
10085         OTLog::vOutput(0, "Failure: processing transaction %ld for nym: %s \n",
10086             lTransactionNumber, msgOut.m_strNymID.Get());
10087     }
10088 }
10089 
10090 
10091 // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
10092 
10093 // After EVERY / ANY transaction, plus certain messages, we drop a copy of the server's reply into
10094 // the Nymbox.  This way we are GUARANTEED that the Nym will receive and process it. (And thus
10095 // never get out of sync.)  This is the function used for doing that.
10096 //
10097 void OTServer::DropReplyNoticeToNymbox(const OTIdentifier & SERVER_ID,
10098                                        const OTIdentifier & USER_ID,
10099                                        const OTString & strMessage,
10100                                        const int64_t & lRequestNum,
10101                                        const bool   bReplyTransSuccess,
10102                                        OTPseudonym * pActualNym/*=NULL*/)
10103 {
10104     OTLedger theNymbox(USER_ID, USER_ID, SERVER_ID);
10105 
10106     bool bSuccessLoadingNymbox = theNymbox.LoadNymbox();
10107 
10108     if (true == bSuccessLoadingNymbox)
10109         bSuccessLoadingNymbox   = (theNymbox.VerifyContractID() && theNymbox.VerifySignature(m_nymServer));
10110 //      bSuccessLoadingNymbox   = theNymbox.VerifyAccount(m_nymServer); // make sure it's all good.
10111 
10112     // --------------------------------------------------------------------
10113     if (false == bSuccessLoadingNymbox)
10114     {
10115         const OTString strNymID(USER_ID);
10116         OTLog::vOutput(0, "OTServer::DropReplyNoticeToNymbox: Failed loading or verifying Nymbox for user: %s\n",
10117                        strNymID.Get());
10118     }
10119     // --------------------------------------------------------------------
10120     else
10121     {
10122         int64_t lReplyNoticeTransNum=0;
10123         bool bGotNextTransNum = IssueNextTransactionNumber(m_nymServer, lReplyNoticeTransNum, false); // bool bStoreTheNumber = false
10124 
10125         if (!bGotNextTransNum)
10126         {
10127             lReplyNoticeTransNum = 0;
10128             OTLog::Error("OTServer::DropReplyNoticeToNymbox: Error getting next transaction number for an OTTransaction::replyNotice.\n");
10129         }
10130         else
10131         {   // Drop in the Nymbox
10132             //
10133             OTTransaction * pReplyNotice = OTTransaction::GenerateTransaction(theNymbox, OTTransaction::replyNotice, lReplyNoticeTransNum);
10134             OT_ASSERT(NULL != pReplyNotice);
10135             // --------------------------------
10136             OTItem * pReplyNoticeItem = OTItem::CreateItemFromTransaction(*pReplyNotice, OTItem::replyNotice);
10137             OT_ASSERT(NULL != pReplyNoticeItem);
10138             // --------------------------------
10139             pReplyNoticeItem->SetStatus(OTItem::acknowledgement); // Nymbox notice is always a success. It's just a notice. (The message inside it will have success/failure also, and any transaction inside that will also.)
10140             pReplyNoticeItem->SetAttachment(strMessage); // Purpose of this notice is to carry a copy of server's reply message (to certain requests, including all transactions.)
10141             pReplyNoticeItem->SignContract(m_nymServer);
10142             pReplyNoticeItem->SaveContract();
10143             // --------------------------------
10144             pReplyNotice->AddItem(*pReplyNoticeItem); // the Transaction's destructor will cleanup the item. It "owns" it now.
10145             // --------------------------------
10146             // So the client-side can quickly/easily match up the replyNotices in
10147             // the Nymbox with the request numbers of the messages that were sent.
10148             // I think this is actually WHY the server message low-level functions
10149             // now RETURN the request number.
10150             // FYI: replyNotices will ONLY be in my Nymbox if the MESSAGE was successful.
10151             // (Meaning, the balance agreement might have failed, and the transaction
10152             // might have failed, but the MESSAGE ITSELF must be a success, in order for
10153             // the replyNotice to appear in the Nymbox.)
10154             //
10155             pReplyNotice->SetRequestNum(lRequestNum);
10156             pReplyNotice->SetReplyTransSuccess(bReplyTransSuccess);
10157             // --------------------------------
10158             pReplyNotice->SignContract(m_nymServer);
10159             pReplyNotice->SaveContract();
10160             // --------------------------------
10161             theNymbox.  AddTransaction(*pReplyNotice); // Add the replyNotice to the nymbox. It takes ownership.
10162             theNymbox.  ReleaseSignatures();
10163             theNymbox.  SignContract(m_nymServer);
10164             theNymbox.  SaveContract();
10165 
10166             OTIdentifier NYMBOX_HASH;
10167             theNymbox.  SaveNymbox(&NYMBOX_HASH);
10168 
10169             pReplyNotice->SaveBoxReceipt(theNymbox);
10170             // -----------------------
10171 
10172             if ((NULL != pActualNym) && pActualNym->CompareID(USER_ID))
10173             {
10174                 pActualNym->SetNymboxHashServerSide(NYMBOX_HASH);
10175                 pActualNym->SaveSignedNymfile(m_nymServer);
10176             }
10177             else if (NULL != pActualNym)
10178                 OTLog::Error("OTServer::DropReplyNoticeToNymbox: ERROR: pActualNym was not NULL, but it didn't match USER_ID.\n");
10179         }
10180     }
10181     // -------------------------------------------------------------
10182 }
10183 
10184 
10185 // Deprecated (replaced by UserCmdGetAccountFiles)
10186 void OTServer::UserCmdGetAccount(OTPseudonym & theNym, OTMessage & MsgIn, OTMessage & msgOut)
10187 {
10188     // (1) set up member variables
10189     msgOut.m_strCommand     = "@getAccount";    // reply to getAccount
10190     msgOut.m_strNymID       = MsgIn.m_strNymID; // UserID
10191 //  msgOut.m_strServerID    = m_strServerID;    // This is already set in ProcessUserCommand.
10192     msgOut.m_strAcctID      = MsgIn.m_strAcctID;    // The Account ID in question
10193 
10194     const OTIdentifier USER_ID(MsgIn.m_strNymID), ACCOUNT_ID(MsgIn.m_strAcctID), SERVER_ID(MsgIn.m_strServerID);
10195 
10196     OTAccount * pAccount        = OTAccount::LoadExistingAccount(ACCOUNT_ID, SERVER_ID);
10197     bool bSuccessLoadingAccount = ((pAccount != NULL) ? true:false );
10198 
10199     // Yup the account exists. Yup it has the same user ID.
10200     if (bSuccessLoadingAccount && (pAccount->GetUserID() == USER_ID))
10201     {
10202         msgOut.m_bSuccess = true;
10203         // extract the account in ascii-armored form on the outgoing message
10204         OTString strPayload(*pAccount); // first grab it in plaintext string form
10205         msgOut.m_ascPayload.SetString(strPayload);  // now the outgoing message has the account in its payload in base64 form.
10206     }
10207     // Send the user's command back to him if failure.
10208     else
10209     {
10210         msgOut.m_bSuccess = false;
10211         OTString tempInMessage(MsgIn); // Grab the incoming message in plaintext form
10212         msgOut.m_ascInReferenceTo.SetString(tempInMessage); // Set it into the base64-encoded object on the outgoing message
10213     }
10214 
10215     // (2) Sign the Message
10216     msgOut.SignContract((const OTPseudonym &)m_nymServer);
10217 
10218     // (3) Save the Message (with signatures and all, back to its internal member m_strRawFile.)
10219     //
10220     // FYI, SaveContract takes m_xmlUnsigned and wraps it with the signatures and ------- BEGIN  bookends
10221     // If you don't pass a string in, then SaveContract saves the new version to its member, m_strRawFile
10222     msgOut.SaveContract();
10223 }
10224 
10225 
10226 void OTServer::UserCmdGetAccountFiles(OTPseudonym & theNym, OTMessage & MsgIn, OTMessage & msgOut)
10227 {
10228     // (1) set up member variables
10229     msgOut.m_strCommand     = "@getAccountFiles";   // reply to getAccountFiles
10230     msgOut.m_strNymID       = MsgIn.m_strNymID;     // UserID
10231 //  msgOut.m_strServerID    = m_strServerID;        // This is already set in ProcessUserCommand.
10232     msgOut.m_strAcctID      = MsgIn.m_strAcctID;    // The Account ID in question
10233 
10234     const OTIdentifier USER_ID(MsgIn.m_strNymID), ACCOUNT_ID(MsgIn.m_strAcctID), SERVER_ID(MsgIn.m_strServerID);
10235 
10236     OTString    strAccount, strInbox, strOutbox, strInboxHash, strOutboxHash;
10237     // ------------------------------------------
10238     OTAccount * pAccount        = OTAccount::LoadExistingAccount(ACCOUNT_ID, SERVER_ID);
10239     bool bSuccessLoadingAccount = ((pAccount != NULL) ? true:false );
10240     bool bSuccessLoadingInbox   = false;
10241     bool bSuccessLoadingOutbox  = false;
10242     // ------------------------------------------
10243     if (bSuccessLoadingAccount)
10244         bSuccessLoadingAccount = (pAccount->GetUserID() == USER_ID);
10245     // ------------------------------------------
10246     // Yup the account exists. Yup it has the same user ID.
10247     if (bSuccessLoadingAccount)
10248     {
10249         // extract the account in ascii-armored form on the outgoing message
10250         pAccount->SaveContractRaw(strAccount); // first grab it in plaintext string form
10251 
10252         // ******************************************************************************
10253         // Get the Inbox.
10254         //
10255         {
10256             OTLedger theInbox(USER_ID, ACCOUNT_ID, SERVER_ID);
10257 
10258             bSuccessLoadingInbox = theInbox.LoadInbox();
10259 
10260             if (!bSuccessLoadingInbox)
10261                 OTLog::vError("%s: Failed trying to load Inbox from storage.\n", __FUNCTION__);
10262             else
10263             {
10264                 // We do NOT call VerifyAccount in this function (because we don't need to) and thus we do NOT
10265                 // force the box receipts to be loaded here (which happens inside that call.) But we DO verify
10266                 // the IDs and the Signature, of course.
10267                 //
10268                 bSuccessLoadingInbox = (theInbox.VerifyContractID() && theInbox.VerifySignature(m_nymServer));
10269 
10270                 // If we loaded old data in this file... (when whole receipts used to be stored in boxes.)
10271                 //
10272                 if (bSuccessLoadingInbox && theInbox.LoadedLegacyData())    // (which automatically saves the box receipt as the old data is loaded...)
10273                 {
10274 //                  bSuccessLoadingInbox = theInbox.VerifyAccount(m_nymServer); // Then Verify, which forces a LoadBoxReceipts... (
10275 
10276                     theInbox.ReleaseSignatures();               // UPDATE: We do NOT force the loading here, since they aren't needed.
10277                     theInbox.SignContract(m_nymServer);     // Waste of resources. Instead, we recognize that it was old data, and so
10278                     theInbox.SaveContract();                    // we gracefully re-save in the new format, so it won't repeatedly be
10279                     theInbox.SaveInbox();                       // loaded over and over again in the large filesize.
10280                 }
10281 
10282                 if (!bSuccessLoadingInbox)
10283                     OTLog::vError("%s: Verification failed on Inbox after loading.\n", __FUNCTION__);
10284             }
10285             // ---------------------------------------------
10286             if (bSuccessLoadingInbox)
10287             {
10288                 theInbox.SaveContractRaw(strInbox);
10289 
10290                 OTIdentifier theHash;
10291                 if (theInbox.CalculateInboxHash(theHash))
10292                     theHash.GetString(strInboxHash);
10293             }
10294         }
10295         // ******************************************************************************
10296         // Now get the OUTBOX.
10297         //
10298         if (bSuccessLoadingInbox) // (Which we don't bother to do unless the inbox was already successful.)
10299         {
10300             OTLedger theOutbox(USER_ID, ACCOUNT_ID, SERVER_ID);
10301 
10302             bSuccessLoadingOutbox = theOutbox.LoadOutbox();
10303 
10304             if (!bSuccessLoadingOutbox)
10305                 OTLog::vError("%s: Failed trying to load Outbox from storage.\n", __FUNCTION__);
10306             else
10307             {
10308                 // We do NOT call VerifyAccount in this function (because we don't need to) and thus we do NOT
10309                 // force the box receipts to be loaded here (which happens inside that call.) But we DO verify
10310                 // the IDs and the Signature, of course.
10311                 //
10312                 bSuccessLoadingOutbox = (theOutbox.VerifyContractID() && theOutbox.VerifySignature(m_nymServer));
10313 
10314                 // If we loaded old data in this file... (when whole receipts used to be stored in boxes.)
10315                 //
10316                 if (bSuccessLoadingOutbox && theOutbox.LoadedLegacyData())  // (which automatically saves the box receipt as the old data is loaded...)
10317                 {
10318 //                  bSuccessLoadingOutbox = theOutbox.VerifyAccount(m_nymServer);   // Then Verify, which forces a LoadBoxReceipts... (
10319 
10320                     theOutbox.ReleaseSignatures();              // UPDATE: We do NOT force the loading here, since they aren't needed.
10321                     theOutbox.SignContract(m_nymServer);        // Waste of resources. Instead, we recognize that it was old data, and so
10322                     theOutbox.SaveContract();                   // we gracefully re-save in the new format, so it won't repeatedly be
10323                     theOutbox.SaveOutbox();                     // loaded over and over again in the large filesize.
10324                 }
10325 
10326                 if (!bSuccessLoadingOutbox)
10327                     OTLog::vError("%s: Verification Failed on Outbox after loading.\n", __FUNCTION__);
10328             }
10329             // -----------------------------------------------
10330             if (bSuccessLoadingOutbox)
10331             {
10332                 theOutbox.SaveContractRaw(strOutbox);
10333 
10334                 OTIdentifier theHash;
10335                 if (theOutbox.CalculateOutboxHash(theHash))
10336                     theHash.GetString(strOutboxHash);
10337             }
10338         }
10339     }
10340     // ******************************************************************************
10341     // TODO optimize: Really only !SuccessLoadingOutbox is needed here.
10342     // If it is false, then the others are definitely false as well.
10343     //
10344     if (!bSuccessLoadingOutbox || !bSuccessLoadingInbox || !bSuccessLoadingAccount)
10345     {
10346         // FAILURE: (Send the user's command back to him.)
10347         //
10348         msgOut.m_bSuccess = false;
10349         OTString tempInMessage(MsgIn); // Grab the incoming message in plaintext form
10350         msgOut.m_ascInReferenceTo.SetString(tempInMessage); // Set it into the base64-encoded object on the outgoing message
10351     }
10352     // ------------------------------------------
10353     else // SUCCESS.
10354     {
10355         // Create an OTDB::StringMap object.
10356         // (To return the three files in.)
10357         //
10358         OTDB::Storable * pStorable = NULL;
10359         OTCleanup<OTDB::Storable> theAngel;
10360         OTDB::StringMap * pMap = NULL;
10361         // --------------------------------------------------------------
10362         pStorable = OTDB::CreateObject(OTDB::STORED_OBJ_STRING_MAP); // this asserts already, on failure.
10363         theAngel.SetCleanupTargetPointer(pStorable); // It will definitely be cleaned up.
10364         pMap = (NULL == pStorable) ? NULL : dynamic_cast<OTDB::StringMap *>(pStorable);
10365         // --------------------------------------------------------------
10366         // It exists.
10367         //
10368         if (NULL == pMap)
10369             OTLog::vError("%s: Error: failed trying to create a STORED_OBJ_STRING_MAP.\n",
10370                           __FUNCTION__);
10371         else
10372         {
10373             // -----------------------------------------------
10374             mapOfStrings & theMap = pMap->the_map;
10375             // -----------------------------------------------
10376             theMap.insert(std::pair<std::string, std::string>("account", strAccount.Get()));
10377             theMap.insert(std::pair<std::string, std::string>("inbox",   strInbox  .Get()));
10378             theMap.insert(std::pair<std::string, std::string>("outbox",  strOutbox .Get()));
10379             // -----------------------------------------------
10380             // Serialize the StringMap to a string...
10381             //
10382             std::string str_Encoded     = OTDB::EncodeObject(*pMap);
10383             const bool bSuccessEncoding = (str_Encoded.size() > 0);
10384 
10385             if (!bSuccessEncoding)
10386                 OTLog::vError("%s: Error: failed trying to encode a STORED_OBJ_STRING_MAP.\n",
10387                               __FUNCTION__);
10388             else
10389             {
10390                 msgOut.m_ascPayload.Set(str_Encoded.c_str()); // <============
10391                 msgOut.m_strInboxHash  = strInboxHash;
10392                 msgOut.m_strOutboxHash = strOutboxHash;
10393                 msgOut.m_bSuccess      = true;
10394             }
10395         }
10396     }
10397     // ------------------------------------------
10398     // (2) Sign the Message
10399     msgOut.SignContract((const OTPseudonym &)m_nymServer);
10400 
10401     // (3) Save the Message (with signatures and all, back to its internal member m_strRawFile.)
10402     //
10403     // FYI, SaveContract takes m_xmlUnsigned and wraps it with the signatures and ------- BEGIN  bookends
10404     // If you don't pass a string in, then SaveContract saves the new version to its member, m_strRawFile
10405     msgOut.SaveContract();
10406 }
10407 
10408 
10409 // Deprecated (replaced by UserCmdGetAccountFiles)
10410 void OTServer::UserCmdGetInbox(OTPseudonym & theNym, OTMessage & MsgIn, OTMessage & msgOut)
10411 {
10412     // (1) set up member variables
10413     msgOut.m_strCommand     = "@getInbox";          // reply to getInbox
10414     msgOut.m_strNymID       = MsgIn.m_strNymID;     // UserID
10415 //  msgOut.m_strServerID    = m_strServerID;        // This is already set in ProcessUserCommand.
10416     msgOut.m_strAcctID      = MsgIn.m_strAcctID;    // The Account ID in question
10417 
10418     const OTIdentifier USER_ID(MsgIn.m_strNymID), ACCOUNT_ID(MsgIn.m_strAcctID), SERVER_ID(MsgIn.m_strServerID);
10419 
10420     OTLedger theLedger(USER_ID, ACCOUNT_ID, SERVER_ID);
10421 
10422     msgOut.m_bSuccess = theLedger.LoadInbox();
10423 
10424     if (!msgOut.m_bSuccess)
10425         OTLog::vError("%s: Failed trying to load Inbox from storage.\n", __FUNCTION__);
10426     else
10427     {
10428         // We do NOT call VerifyAccount in this function (because we don't need to) and thus we do NOT
10429         // force the box receipts to be loaded here (which happens inside that call.) But we DO verify
10430         // the IDs and the Signature, of course.
10431         //
10432         msgOut.m_bSuccess = (theLedger.VerifyContractID() && theLedger.VerifySignature(m_nymServer));
10433 
10434         // If we loaded old data in this file... (when whole receipts were stored in boxes.)
10435         //
10436         if (msgOut.m_bSuccess && theLedger.LoadedLegacyData())  // (which automatically saves the box receipt as the old data is loaded...)
10437         {
10438 //          msgOut.m_bSuccess = theLedger.VerifyAccount(m_nymServer);   // Then Verify, which forces a LoadBoxReceipts... (
10439 
10440             theLedger.ReleaseSignatures();              // UPDATE: We do NOT force the loading here, since they aren't needed.
10441             theLedger.SignContract(m_nymServer);        // Waste of resources. Instead, we recognize that it was old data, and so
10442             theLedger.SaveContract();                   // we gracefully re-save in the new format, so it won't repeatedly be
10443             theLedger.SaveInbox();                      // loaded over and over again in the large filesize.
10444         }
10445 
10446         if (!msgOut.m_bSuccess)
10447             OTLog::vError("%s: Verification failed on Inbox after loading.\n", __FUNCTION__);
10448     }
10449 
10450     if (msgOut.m_bSuccess)
10451     {
10452         // extract the ledger in ascii-armored form on the outgoing message
10453         OTString strPayload(theLedger); // first grab it in plaintext string form
10454         msgOut.m_ascPayload.SetString(strPayload);  // now the outgoing message has the inbox ledger in its payload in base64 form.
10455 
10456         OTIdentifier theHash;
10457         if (theLedger.CalculateInboxHash(theHash))
10458             theHash.GetString(msgOut.m_strInboxHash);
10459     }
10460     // Send the user's command back to him if failure.
10461     else
10462     {
10463         OTString tempInMessage(MsgIn); // Grab the incoming message in plaintext form
10464         msgOut.m_ascInReferenceTo.SetString(tempInMessage); // Set it into the base64-encoded object on the outgoing message
10465     }
10466 
10467     // (2) Sign the Message
10468     msgOut.SignContract((const OTPseudonym &)m_nymServer); // todo const cast
10469 
10470     // (3) Save the Message (with signatures and all, back to its internal member m_strRawFile.)
10471     //
10472     // FYI, SaveContract takes m_xmlUnsigned and wraps it with the signatures and ------- BEGIN  bookends
10473     // If you don't pass a string in, then SaveContract saves the new version to its member, m_strRawFile
10474     msgOut.SaveContract();
10475 }
10476 
10477 
10478 // Deprecated (replaced by UserCmdGetAccountFiles)
10479 void OTServer::UserCmdGetOutbox(OTPseudonym & theNym, OTMessage & MsgIn, OTMessage & msgOut)
10480 {
10481     // (1) set up member variables
10482     msgOut.m_strCommand     = "@getOutbox";         // reply to getOutbox
10483     msgOut.m_strNymID       = MsgIn.m_strNymID;     // UserID
10484 //  msgOut.m_strServerID    = m_strServerID;        // This is already set in ProcessUserCommand.
10485     msgOut.m_strAcctID      = MsgIn.m_strAcctID;    // The Account ID in question
10486 
10487     const OTIdentifier USER_ID(MsgIn.m_strNymID), ACCOUNT_ID(MsgIn.m_strAcctID), SERVER_ID(MsgIn.m_strServerID);
10488 
10489     OTLedger theLedger(USER_ID, ACCOUNT_ID, SERVER_ID);
10490 
10491     msgOut.m_bSuccess = theLedger.LoadOutbox();
10492 
10493     if (!msgOut.m_bSuccess)
10494         OTLog::vError("%s: Failed trying to load Outbox from storage.\n", __FUNCTION__);
10495     else
10496     {
10497         // We do NOT call VerifyAccount in this function (because we don't need to) and thus we do NOT
10498         // force the box receipts to be loaded here (which happens inside that call.) But we DO verify
10499         // the IDs and the Signature, of course.
10500         //
10501         msgOut.m_bSuccess = (theLedger.VerifyContractID() && theLedger.VerifySignature(m_nymServer));
10502 
10503         // If we loaded old data in this file... (when whole receipts were stored in boxes.)
10504         //
10505         if (msgOut.m_bSuccess && theLedger.LoadedLegacyData())  // (which automatically saves the box receipt as the old data is loaded...)
10506         {
10507 //          msgOut.m_bSuccess = theLedger.VerifyAccount(m_nymServer);   // Then Verify, which forces a LoadBoxReceipts... (
10508 
10509             theLedger.ReleaseSignatures();              // UPDATE: We do NOT force the loading here, since they aren't needed.
10510             theLedger.SignContract(m_nymServer);        // Waste of resources. Instead, we recognize that it was old data, and so
10511             theLedger.SaveContract();                   // we gracefully re-save in the new format, so it won't repeatedly be
10512             theLedger.SaveOutbox();                     // loaded over and over again in the large filesize.
10513         }
10514 
10515         if (!msgOut.m_bSuccess)
10516             OTLog::vError("%s: Verification Failed on Outbox after loading.\n", __FUNCTION__);
10517     }
10518 
10519     if (msgOut.m_bSuccess)
10520     {
10521         // extract the ledger in ascii-armored form on the outgoing message
10522         OTString strPayload(theLedger); // first grab it in plaintext string form
10523         msgOut.m_ascPayload.SetString(strPayload);  // now the outgoing message has the outbox ledger in its payload in base64 form.
10524 
10525         OTIdentifier theHash;
10526         if (theLedger.CalculateOutboxHash(theHash))
10527             theHash.GetString(msgOut.m_strOutboxHash);
10528     }
10529     // Send the user's command back to him if failure.
10530     else
10531     {
10532         OTString tempInMessage(MsgIn); // Grab the incoming message in plaintext form
10533         msgOut.m_ascInReferenceTo.SetString(tempInMessage); // Set it into the base64-encoded object on the outgoing message
10534     }
10535 
10536     // (2) Sign the Message
10537     msgOut.SignContract((const OTPseudonym &)m_nymServer);
10538 
10539     // (3) Save the Message (with signatures and all, back to its internal member m_strRawFile.)
10540     //
10541     // FYI, SaveContract takes m_xmlUnsigned and wraps it with the signatures and ------- BEGIN  bookends
10542     // If you don't pass a string in, then SaveContract saves the new version to its member, m_strRawFile
10543     msgOut.SaveContract();
10544 }
10545 
10546 
10547 
10548 void OTServer::UserCmdQueryAssetTypes(OTPseudonym & theNym, OTMessage & MsgIn, OTMessage & msgOut)
10549 {
10550     // (1) set up member variables
10551     msgOut.m_strCommand     = "@queryAssetTypes";   // reply to queryAssetTypes
10552     msgOut.m_strNymID       = MsgIn.m_strNymID;     // UserID
10553 //  msgOut.m_strServerID    = m_strServerID;    // This is already set in ProcessUserCommand.
10554     msgOut.m_bSuccess       = false;                // so far.
10555 
10556     // Send the user's command back to him whether success or failure.
10557     OTString tempInMessage(MsgIn); // Grab the incoming message in plaintext form
10558     msgOut.m_ascInReferenceTo.SetString(tempInMessage); // Set it into the base64-encoded object on the outgoing message
10559 
10560     if (MsgIn.m_ascPayload.Exists()) // (which it should)
10561     {
10562         OTDB::Storable * pStorable = OTDB::DecodeObject(OTDB::STORED_OBJ_STRING_MAP, MsgIn.m_ascPayload.Get());
10563         OTCleanup<OTDB::Storable> theAngel(pStorable); // It will definitely be cleaned up.
10564         OTDB::StringMap * pMap = (NULL == pStorable) ? NULL : dynamic_cast<OTDB::StringMap *>(pStorable);
10565 
10566         if (NULL != pMap) // There was definitely a StringMap in the payload.
10567         {
10568             msgOut.m_bSuccess = true;
10569 
10570             std::map<std::string, std::string> & theMap = pMap->the_map;
10571             std::map<std::string, std::string> theNewMap;
10572 
10573             FOR_EACH(mapOfStrings, theMap)
10574             {
10575                 const std::string & str1 = (*it).first; // Containing the asset type ID.
10576                 const std::string & str2 = (*it).second;    // Containing the phrase "exists". (More are possible in the future.)
10577                 // --------------------------------
10578 
10579                 // todo security: limit on length of this map? (sent through user message...)
10580 
10581                 // "exists" means, "Here's an asset ID. Please tell me
10582                 // whether or not it's actually issued on this server."
10583                 // Future options might include "issue", "audit", "contract",
10584                 // etc.
10585                 //
10586                 if ((str1.size() > 0) && (str2.compare("exists") == 0)) // todo hardcoding
10587                 {
10588                     const OTIdentifier theAssetID(str1.c_str());
10589                     OTAssetContract * pAssetContract = GetAssetContract(theAssetID);
10590                     // -----------------------------------
10591                     if (NULL != pAssetContract) // Yes, it exists.
10592                         theNewMap[str1] = "true";
10593                     else
10594                         theNewMap[str1] = "false";
10595                 }
10596             } // FOR_EACH
10597 
10598             // Replace contents of old map with contents of new map.
10599             //
10600             theMap.clear();
10601             theMap = theNewMap;
10602             // -----------------------------
10603             // Serialize the StringMap back to a string...
10604 
10605             std::string str_Encoded = OTDB::EncodeObject(*pMap);
10606 
10607             if (str_Encoded.size() > 0)
10608                 msgOut.m_ascPayload = str_Encoded.c_str();  // now the outgoing message has the response map in its payload, in base64 form.
10609             else
10610                 msgOut.m_bSuccess = false; // Something went wrong.
10611         } // if pMap exists.
10612     }
10613     else
10614     {
10615         msgOut.m_bSuccess = false;
10616     }
10617 
10618     // (2) Sign the Message
10619     msgOut.SignContract((const OTPseudonym &)m_nymServer);
10620 
10621     // (3) Save the Message (with signatures and all, back to its internal member m_strRawFile.)
10622     //
10623     // FYI, SaveContract takes m_xmlUnsigned and wraps it with the signatures and ------- BEGIN  bookends
10624     // If you don't pass a string in, then SaveContract saves the new version to its member, m_strRawFile
10625     msgOut.SaveContract();
10626 }
10627 
10628 
10629 
10630 
10631 void OTServer::UserCmdGetContract(OTPseudonym & theNym, OTMessage & MsgIn, OTMessage & msgOut)
10632 {
10633     // (1) set up member variables
10634     msgOut.m_strCommand     = "@getContract";   // reply to getContract
10635     msgOut.m_strNymID       = MsgIn.m_strNymID; // UserID
10636     //  msgOut.m_strServerID    = m_strServerID;    // This is already set in ProcessUserCommand.
10637     msgOut.m_strAssetID     = MsgIn.m_strAssetID;   // The Asset Type ID in question
10638 
10639     const OTIdentifier ASSET_TYPE_ID(MsgIn.m_strAssetID);
10640 
10641     OTAssetContract * pContract = GetAssetContract(ASSET_TYPE_ID);
10642 
10643     bool bSuccessLoadingContract = ((pContract != NULL) ? true:false );
10644 
10645     // Yup the asset contract exists.
10646     if (bSuccessLoadingContract)
10647     {
10648         msgOut.m_bSuccess = true;
10649         // extract the account in ascii-armored form on the outgoing message
10650         OTString strPayload(*pContract); // first grab it in plaintext string form
10651         msgOut.m_ascPayload.SetString(strPayload);  // now the outgoing message has the contract in its payload in base64 form.
10652     }
10653     // Send the user's command back to him if failure.
10654     else
10655     {
10656         msgOut.m_bSuccess = false;
10657         OTString tempInMessage(MsgIn); // Grab the incoming message in plaintext form
10658         msgOut.m_ascInReferenceTo.SetString(tempInMessage); // Set it into the base64-encoded object on the outgoing message
10659     }
10660 
10661     // (2) Sign the Message
10662     msgOut.SignContract((const OTPseudonym &)m_nymServer); 
10663 
10664     // (3) Save the Message (with signatures and all, back to its internal member m_strRawFile.)
10665     //
10666     // FYI, SaveContract takes m_xmlUnsigned and wraps it with the signatures and ------- BEGIN  bookends
10667     // If you don't pass a string in, then SaveContract saves the new version to its member, m_strRawFile
10668     msgOut.SaveContract();
10669 }
10670 
10671 
10672 
10673 
10674 
10675 // Done.
10676 //
10677 void OTServer::UserCmdTriggerClause(OTPseudonym & theNym, OTMessage & MsgIn, OTMessage & msgOut)
10678 {
10679     OTString strInReferenceTo(MsgIn); // Grab the incoming message in plaintext form
10680     msgOut.m_ascInReferenceTo.SetString(strInReferenceTo);
10681     // ---------------------------------------------
10682     // (1) set up member variables
10683     msgOut.m_strCommand     = "@triggerClause"; // reply to triggerClause
10684     msgOut.m_strNymID       = MsgIn.m_strNymID; // UserID
10685 //  msgOut.m_strServerID    = m_strServerID;    // This is already set in ProcessUserCommand.
10686     msgOut.m_bSuccess       = false;            // Default value.
10687     // ------------------------------------------------------------
10688     const
10689     OTIdentifier  SERVER_ID(m_strServerID),
10690                   theMsgNymboxHash(MsgIn.m_strNymboxHash); // theMsgNymboxHash is the hash sent by the client side
10691     OTIdentifier  theSrvrNymboxHash;
10692 
10693     bool bGotNymboxHashServerSide = theNym.GetNymboxHashServerSide(SERVER_ID, theSrvrNymboxHash);
10694     const
10695     bool bGotNymboxHashClientSide = MsgIn.m_strNymboxHash.Exists();
10696 
10697     if (bGotNymboxHashServerSide)  // theSrvrNymboxHash is the hash stored on the server side
10698         theSrvrNymboxHash.GetString(msgOut.m_strNymboxHash);
10699     // -------------------------------------------------------------
10700     if (
10701         (bGotNymboxHashServerSide && bGotNymboxHashClientSide && (theMsgNymboxHash != theSrvrNymboxHash))
10702         ||
10703         (bGotNymboxHashServerSide && !bGotNymboxHashClientSide)
10704         )
10705     {
10706         OTLog::vOutput(0, "%s: Rejecting message since nymbox hash doesn't match. "
10707                        "(Send a getNymbox message to grab the newest one.)\n",
10708                        __FUNCTION__);
10709     }
10710     // ------------------------------------------------------------
10711     else
10712     {
10713         OTSmartContract * pSmartContract = NULL;
10714         // ---------------------------------------------
10715         OTCronItem * pCronItem = m_Cron.GetItemByValidOpeningNum(MsgIn.m_lTransactionNum);
10716 
10717         if (NULL == pCronItem)
10718         {
10719             OTLog::vOutput(0, "%s: Couldn't find smart contract based on transaction #: %ld \n",
10720                            __FUNCTION__, MsgIn.m_lTransactionNum);
10721         }
10722         // -----------------------------------------
10723         // Also: CAN this guy trigger it?
10724         else if (NULL == (pSmartContract = dynamic_cast<OTSmartContract *> (pCronItem)))
10725         {
10726             OTLog::vOutput(0, "%s: Found cron item %ld based on %ld, but it wasn't a "
10727                            "smart contract. \n", __FUNCTION__, pCronItem->GetTransactionNum(),
10728                            MsgIn.m_lTransactionNum);
10729         }
10730         // -----------------------------------------
10731         else
10732         {
10733             // FIND THE PARTY / PARTY NAME
10734             OTAgent * pAgent = NULL;
10735             OTParty * pParty = pSmartContract->FindPartyBasedOnNymAsAgent(theNym, &pAgent);
10736 
10737             if (NULL == pParty)
10738             {
10739                 OTLog::vOutput(0, "%s: Unable to find party to this contract (%ld based on %ld) "
10740                                "based on Nym as agent: %s", __FUNCTION__, pCronItem->GetTransactionNum(),
10741                                MsgIn.m_lTransactionNum, MsgIn.m_strNymID.Get());
10742             }
10743             else
10744             {
10745                 bool bSuccess = false;
10746                 const std::string str_clause_name = MsgIn.m_strNymID2.Get();
10747 
10748                 if (pSmartContract->CanExecuteClause(pParty->GetPartyName(), str_clause_name)) // This calls (if available) the scripted clause: bool party_may_execute_clause(party_name, clause_name)
10749                 {
10750                     // *****************************************************************************
10751                     //
10752                     // Execute the clause.
10753                     //
10754                     mapOfClauses theMatchingClauses;
10755                     OTClause * pClause = pSmartContract->GetClause(str_clause_name);
10756 
10757                     if (NULL != pClause)
10758                     {
10759                         OTLog::vOutput(0, "%s: At party request, processing smart contract clause: %s \n",
10760                                        __FUNCTION__, str_clause_name.c_str());
10761 
10762                         theMatchingClauses.insert(std::pair<std::string, OTClause*>(str_clause_name, pClause));
10763 
10764                         pSmartContract->ExecuteClauses(theMatchingClauses); // <============================================
10765 
10766                         if (pSmartContract->IsFlaggedForRemoval())
10767                         {
10768                             OTLog::vOutput(0, "%s: Removing smart contract from cron processing: %ld\n",
10769                                            __FUNCTION__, pSmartContract->GetTransactionNum());
10770                         }
10771                         bSuccess = true;
10772                     }
10773                     else
10774                     {
10775                         OTLog::vOutput(0, "%s: Failed attempt to process clause (%s) on smart contract: %ld \n",
10776                                        __FUNCTION__, str_clause_name.c_str(), pSmartContract->GetTransactionNum());
10777                     }
10778                 }
10779                 // *****************************************************************************
10780 
10781                 // If we just removed the smart contract from cron, that means a finalReceipt was just dropped
10782                 // into the inboxes for the relevant asset accounts. Once I process that receipt out of my
10783                 // inbox, (which will require my processing out all related marketReceipts) then the closing
10784                 // number will be removed from my list of responsibility.
10785 
10786                 if (bSuccess)
10787                 {
10788                     // Now we can set the response item as an acknowledgement instead of the default (rejection)
10789                     OTLog::vOutput(0, "%s: Party (%s) successfully triggered clause: %s.\n",
10790                                    __FUNCTION__, pParty->GetPartyName().c_str(), str_clause_name.c_str());
10791 
10792                     msgOut.m_bSuccess =  true;
10793                 }
10794                 else
10795                     OTLog::vOutput(0, "%s:  Unable to trigger clause %s at request of party %s. "
10796                                    "(Either the permission wasn't there, or the clause wasn't found.)\n",
10797                                    __FUNCTION__, str_clause_name.c_str(), pParty->GetPartyName().c_str());
10798             } // pParty != NULL
10799         } // else found smart contract.
10800     } // NymboxHash matches.
10801     // -------------------------------------------------
10802     bGotNymboxHashServerSide = theNym.GetNymboxHashServerSide(SERVER_ID, theSrvrNymboxHash);
10803 
10804     if (bGotNymboxHashServerSide)  // theSrvrNymboxHash is the hash stored on the server side
10805         theSrvrNymboxHash.GetString(msgOut.m_strNymboxHash);
10806     // -------------------------------------------------------------
10807     // (2) Sign the Message
10808     msgOut.SignContract((const OTPseudonym &)m_nymServer); // todo change this cast.
10809 
10810     // (3) Save the Message (with signatures and all, back to its internal member m_strRawFile.)
10811     //
10812     // FYI, SaveContract takes m_xmlUnsigned and wraps it with the signatures and ------- BEGIN  bookends
10813     // If you don't pass a string in, then SaveContract saves the new version to its member, m_strRawFile
10814     msgOut.SaveContract();
10815 }
10816 
10817 
10818 
10819 
10820 void OTServer::UserCmdGetMint(OTPseudonym & theNym, OTMessage & MsgIn, OTMessage & msgOut)
10821 {
10822     // (1) set up member variables
10823     msgOut.m_strCommand     = "@getMint";   // reply to getMint
10824     msgOut.m_strNymID       = MsgIn.m_strNymID; // UserID
10825 //  msgOut.m_strServerID    = m_strServerID;    // This is already set in ProcessUserCommand.
10826     msgOut.m_strAssetID     = MsgIn.m_strAssetID;   // The Asset Type ID in question
10827 
10828     const OTIdentifier  ASSET_TYPE_ID(MsgIn.m_strAssetID);
10829     const OTString      ASSET_ID_STR(ASSET_TYPE_ID);
10830     // --------------------------------------------------------------------
10831     bool bSuccessLoadingMint = false;
10832 
10833     OTMint * pMint = OTMint::MintFactory(m_strServerID, ASSET_ID_STR);
10834     OTCleanup<OTMint> theMintAngel(pMint);
10835     OT_ASSERT(NULL != pMint);
10836     // --------------------------------------------------------------------
10837     if (true == (bSuccessLoadingMint = pMint->LoadMint(".PUBLIC")))
10838     {
10839         // You cannot hash the Mint to get its ID.
10840         // (The ID is a hash of the asset contract, not the mint contract.)
10841         // Instead, you must READ the ID from the Mint file, and then compare it to the one expected
10842         // to see if they match (similar to how Account IDs are verified.)
10843 
10844         bSuccessLoadingMint = pMint->VerifyMint(m_nymServer);
10845 
10846         // Yup the asset contract exists.
10847         if (bSuccessLoadingMint)
10848         {
10849             msgOut.m_bSuccess = true;
10850 
10851             // extract the account in ascii-armored form on the outgoing message
10852             OTString strPayload(*pMint); // first grab it in plaintext string form
10853             msgOut.m_ascPayload.SetString(strPayload);  // now the outgoing message has the inbox ledger in its payload in base64 form.
10854         }
10855         // Send the user's command back to him if failure.
10856     }
10857 
10858     if (!bSuccessLoadingMint)
10859     {
10860         msgOut.m_bSuccess = false;
10861         OTString tempInMessage(MsgIn); // Grab the incoming message in plaintext form
10862         msgOut.m_ascInReferenceTo.SetString(tempInMessage); // Set it into the base64-encoded object on the outgoing message
10863     }
10864 
10865     // (2) Sign the Message
10866     msgOut.SignContract((const OTPseudonym &)m_nymServer);
10867 
10868     // (3) Save the Message (with signatures and all, back to its internal member m_strRawFile.)
10869     //
10870     // FYI, SaveContract takes m_xmlUnsigned and wraps it with the signatures and ------- BEGIN  bookends
10871     // If you don't pass a string in, then SaveContract saves the new version to its member, m_strRawFile
10872     msgOut.SaveContract();
10873 }
10874 
10875 
10876 
10877 // If a user requests to delete his own Nym, the server will allow it.
10878 // IF: If the transaction numbers are all closable (available on both lists).
10879 // AND if the Nymbox is empty. AND if there are no cron items open, AND if
10880 // there are no asset accounts! (Delete them / Close them all FIRST! Or this fails.)
10881 //
10882 void OTServer::UserCmdDeleteUser(OTPseudonym & theNym, OTMessage & MsgIn, OTMessage & msgOut)
10883 {
10884     // (1) set up member variables
10885     msgOut.m_strCommand     = "@deleteUserAccount"; // reply to deleteUserAccount
10886     msgOut.m_strNymID       = MsgIn.m_strNymID; // UserID
10887 //  msgOut.m_strServerID    = m_strServerID;    // This is already set in ProcessUserCommand.
10888 
10889     const OTIdentifier USER_ID(MsgIn.m_strNymID), SERVER_ID(MsgIn.m_strServerID);
10890 
10891     OTLedger theLedger(USER_ID, USER_ID, SERVER_ID);
10892
